attributes.title: The best place to invest in renewable energy
attributes.author: Armin Babic
attributes.contentA: The rapid development of many industries, urbanization, and economic growth are causing increased global demands for energy supply. By 2040, a 1.2% yearly increase in energy supply is predicted.
attributes.contentB: By signing the Energy Community Establishment Agreement, Bosnia and Herzegovina joined other members to create the largest internal market for electricity and gas at the global level.
attributes.contentC: As one of the signatories of this Agreement, Bosnia and Herzegovina commits to implementing the AQUIS communautaire in the fields of energy, environment, competition, and renewable energy. With abundant natural resources, favorable hydro and solar conditions, and significant forest coverage relative to its territory size, Bosnia and Herzegovina has an excellent perspective for implementing the Green Agenda and generating energy from renewable sources.
attributes.contentD: Despite being the only net exporter of electricity in the Western Balkans, Bosnia and Herzegovina incurs significant costs of air pollution and health impacts due to the dominance of fossil fuels in its current energy structure. According to 2021 data, the total electricity production in Bosnia and Herzegovina was 17 TWh, with 62% from coal, 35% from hydro, and the rest from solar and wind energy. In order to meet the goals of the Green Deal, Bosnia and Herzegovina recently confirmed its intention to achieve a 43.6% share of renewable sources in gross final consumption by 2030. In other words, according to Bosnia and Herzegovina’s energy policy, the plan is to obtain 85% of energy from hydropower by 2035, 9% from wind, 2% from solar, and 4% from biomass.
attributes.contentE: To date, integrated short-term and long-term strategies aimed at increasing the share of various renewable sources ensure Bosnia and Herzegovina’s energy security and enhance its readiness to join the European Union. In accordance with the current laws in Bosnia and Herzegovina, foreign investors are guaranteed, among other things, the same rights and obligations as domestic investors. They have the same property rights as domestic investors, are protected from nationalization, expropriation, and requisition, and have the right to transfer profits abroad. These rights cannot be nullified by subsequently enacted laws.
attributes.contentF: The tax system and incentives provide an additional advantage for Bosnia and Herzegovina compared to other countries, considering it has one of the most favorable tax systems in Europe (VAT rate of 17%, corporate tax rate of 10%). The corporate tax system also brings numerous benefits in certain parts of the country, such as the exemption from corporate tax in double the amount of the export value resulting from production. This implies that producers would be completely exempt from corporate tax with 50% of the produced and exported electricity.
attributes.contentG: There are also other incentives for investment, a reduction in the tax base up to a certain level, and exemptions from import duties for equipment used in production not manufactured in Bosnia and Herzegovina. This applies to equipment imported for new or expanded production, production modernization, the introduction of new or modernization of existing production technology, directly related to manufacturing activities.
attributes.contentH: However, in the near future, network limitations pose a risk. This initiative in Bosnia and Herzegovina is still on its reform path, and this may affect the speed and adequacy of project implementation.
attributes.contentI: To contribute to the transition to a fossil fuel-free economy, it is crucial to choose “cleaner” projects that will benefit the overall community.

attributes.title: Future ESG trends in Bosnia and Herzegovina
attributes.author: Armin Babic
attributes.contentA: Despite entering the corporate vocabulary in early 2004, the term ESG (Environmental, Social, Governance) has remained invisible for more than a decade.However, with the intensification of the topic of global warming, ESG has become a big part of the discussion and a star determinant for today’s companies. The concept of ESG could be seen as a set of standards that unites the most important issues in the process of implementing the principles of sustainable development, i.e., respecting the criteria that companies use to increase the ethics of their operations. National and international regulatory bodies have begun to evaluate and implement a range of practices related to sustainable finance, focusing primarily on possible ESG access and marketing to investors.Since the nature of the topic is diverse, it is natural that different interests of companies and governments around the world pursue different agendas and, of course, question the overall effort. The difference between countries around the world will make it difficult for global companies to set their own ESG agenda while also complying with the different local regulations of the countries in which they are located.The “Environment” part of ESG remains a priority, because climate differences are increasing, and decarbonization at the micro and macro level conditions the further development of the economy. In addition to climate change, a topic within the “E” part that will be interesting to follow is the topic of biodiversity protection.For this year, it is predicted that the most attention will be paid to the now neglected “Social” part of ESG. By this we mean the issues of equality of wages, work, early participation in management committees.“Governance” in ESG refers to the governance factors involved in decision-making, from policy-making to the distribution of rights and responsibilities among various actors in corporations, including management and stakeholders.
attributes.contentB: Investors looking at an ESG-oriented company will want to ensure that its accounting and reporting systems are reliable and transparent. Also, investors will evaluate how the firm treats its shareholders, as well as their ability to vote on important issues; they will also want evidence that the corporation is not engaging in illegal activities.In summary, the ESG trends that should be followed this year are related to the further development of ESG regulation and reporting standards on the national and international market. The development of this trend is driven by individual companies that will have to be more transparent regarding the actions taken and the final results.

attributes.title: Explore investment opportunities in Bosnia and Herzegovina
attributes.author: Armin Babic
attributes.contentA: In order to attract foreign investment capital in 2025, IA Law Firm Bosnia presents a brief guide to investment opportunities in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Located at the crossroads of Southeastern and Southern Europe, this small but economically growing Balkan country offers rich opportunities for investment. Natural resources, a strategic geographic location, and a comprehensive legal framework make BiH an attractive destination for global investors.
attributes.contentB: Key Characteristics of Bosnia and Herzegovina
attributes.contentC: * Geography and Climate: BiH has a diverse landscape of dense forests, river systems, and a modest coastline along the Adriatic Sea, offering opportunities in forestry, hydropower, and tourism. Notably, BiH has more waterfalls than Italy, France, and Germany combined.
attributes.contentD: * Energy Potential: Bosnia and Herzegovina is over four times more energy-intensive than the EU average and has the highest energy intensity in the Western Balkans. The residential sector is responsible for the largest share of total energy consumption and has significant potential for improvements. BiH has considerable renewable energy potential, particularly in hydroelectric and wind power capacities. According to a study conducted by the German government, BiH could produce up to 2000 MW of wind energy annually, primarily in the Livno, Tomislavgrad, Mostar, and Trebinje areas. This emerging industry still faces several regulatory and financial challenges.
attributes.contentE: * Natural Resources: From coal, iron ore, lithium, and gold to abundant forests and hydropower, Bosnia and Herzegovina’s natural wealth forms the basis for industrial development.
attributes.contentL: BiH consists of two entities (Federation of BiH and Republika Srpska) and the Brčko District. Investors are offered a unique market with specific legislations for each entity. Key aspects include:
attributes.contentM: * Foreign investors have the same rights and obligations as residents of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
attributes.contentN: * Foreign investors can open bank accounts at any commercial bank in local or freely convertible currencies.
attributes.contentO: * Foreign investors have the right to freely employ foreign nationals, unless the laws of BiH stipulate otherwise.
attributes.contentP: * Foreign investors have the same property rights over real estate as domestic legal entities.
attributes.contentR: * Foreign investors are protected from nationalization, expropriation, requisition, and measures with the same effect; such measures can only be taken in the public interest, in accordance with applicable laws and regulations, and with payment of fair compensation.
attributes.contentS: * Foreign investors have the right to transfer profits abroad, which result from their operations in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
attributes.contentU: * After 2015, with the signing of the Stabilization and Association Agreement (SAA) between the European Union (EU) and Bosnia and Herzegovina (BiH), BiH obtained candidate status for EU membership. In March 2024, the European Council decided to open accession negotiations with BiH.
attributes.contentV: * Free Trade Agreement (CEFTA) with North Macedonia, Serbia, Albania, Moldova, Montenegro, and Kosovo.
attributes.contentZ: * Free Trade Agreement with EFTA countries: Switzerland, Norway, Iceland, and Liechtenstein.
attributes.conclusion: * Bosnia and Herzegovina also has a signed Free Trade Agreement with Turkey, providing access to a market of 70 million people.
attributes.textA: BiH has a preferential trading system with New Zealand, Japan, Australia, and the countries of the Eurasian Economic Union.
attributes.textB: Bosnia and Herzegovina has signed double taxation avoidance agreements with the following countries:
attributes.textC: Albania, Algeria, Austria, Azerbaijan, Belgium, Montenegro, Czech Republic, Finland, France, Greece, Croatia, Netherlands, Iran, Ireland, Italy, Jordan, Kuwait, Qatar, China, Cyprus, Hungary, Malaysia, North Macedonia, Moldova, Norway, Germany, Pakistan, Poland, Romania, Slovakia, Slovenia, Serbia, Spain, Sweden, Sri Lanka, Turkey, UAE, the UK, and Northern Ireland.
attributes.textD: Given these relationships, establishing a business in BiH presents an opportunity to export to a market of nearly 600 million people, without paying customs duties.
attributes.textH: * Free trade zones offer VAT exemptions and simplified business operations.
attributes.textJ: * Federation of BiH: 31% of gross salary.
attributes.textN: Legal regulations allow the employment of foreigners with the necessary permits.
attributes.textO: Tax incentives are available for companies employing BiH nationals.

attributes.title: Investing in solar power plants in Bosnia and Herzegovina
attributes.author: Armin Babic
attributes.contentA: In times of accelerated energy transition and increasing demand for sustainable sources of electricity, Bosnia and Herzegovina is emerging as a new, still underutilized, but extremely attractive destination for investing in solar power plants.Thanks to favorable natural, infrastructural and regulatory conditions, investing in medium and large-capacity solar power plants is becoming one of the safest and most profitable investments in the Southeast European region.
attributes.contentB: Ideal climatic and geographical conditions for solar energy production
attributes.contentC: Bosnia and Herzegovina is located in a zone of high insolation, with an annual average of 1,800 to 2,200 hours of sunshine, especially in Herzegovina and Southeast Bosnia. This climate allows for high efficiency of solar panels throughout the year, with minimal seasonal fluctuations in production.
attributes.contentD: In addition, the terrain configuration, low air pollution and low foggy days additionally contribute to a high utilization factor, resulting in a faster return on investment and long-term stable income.
attributes.contentF: Unlike markets in the European Union where land, connection and permit costs are often a limiting factor, BiH offers affordable locations that are ideal for solar power plants. Many of these locations have already passed key preparation stages, including:
attributes.contentH: * Urban planning consent or ready location information
attributes.contentI: * Possibility of rapid integration into the electricity grid
attributes.contentJ: * Proximity to access roads and logistical convenience
attributes.contentK: Energy system open to the development of RES
attributes.contentL: Bosnia and Herzegovina is an exporter of electricity, with a developed transmission network and direct connections to the EU and Western Balkan markets. This makes the sale of produced solar energy simple and competitive, whether through a balance group, market sales or long-term Power Purchase Agreements (PPA) with large buyers.
attributes.contentO: By the end of 2024, the total installed capacity of solar power plants in Bosnia and Herzegovina has reached 153 MW, of which 74 MW is located in the Republika Srpska, and 79 MW in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Although this growth shows a positive trend, the solar energy sector still occupies only 0.14% of the total electricity production in the country.
attributes.contentP: At the same time, an additional 752.5 MW is planned through projects that are in various stages of development – ​​from initial planning to final preparation for construction. If these projects were realized, the total capacity of solar power plants in BiH would reach approximately 900 MW, which would significantly increase the role of the sun in the country's energy mix.
attributes.contentR: However, the reality of domestic energy is still strongly based on fossil fuels, primarily coal, which accounts for about 60% of total electricity production, while hydropower participates with 33%. This production structure is not only a challenge in the context of environmental protection and climate goals, but also an increasingly serious problem in the context of sustainability, emission costs and compliance with EU regulations.
attributes.contentS: Replacing coal with renewable energy sources is one of the key steps to meet the international obligations that BiH has undertaken within the framework of the Energy Community and the Green Deal. At the same time, it is also a huge development and investment opportunity.
attributes.contentT: For investors, this represents a valuable entry point: a market that is only at the beginning of a serious transition, with great room for growth and a high return on investment. The projects being developed today could be key pillars of the new energy map of BiH in the coming decades – and bring long-term stability and income to those who recognize the opportunity in time.
attributes.contentU: Conclusion: An opportunity for those who think strategically
attributes.contentV: Investing in industrial solar power plants in Bosnia and Herzegovina represents a rare combination of high natural potential, a favorable investment environment and growing regional demand for green energy. The time to enter is now, while the market still offers competitive terms and a range of opportunities for partners seeking long-term security and sustainable returns.
attributes.conclusion: Find RES investment opportunities here: https://www.investinbalkan.com/projects

attributes.title: Record Investments in renewable energy (RES)
attributes.author: Armin Babic
attributes.contentA: According to the latest data from the International Energy Agency (IEA), investments in renewable energy have surpassed $2 trillion, more than double the amount invested in fossil fuels. Record Investments in renewable energy - This figure is not just a shift in investment structure, it symbolizes a profound and lasting change towards a more sustainable, safer, and financially viable energy future.
attributes.contentB: The majority of investments come from China (around $680 billion), the European Union (over $370 billion), and the United States (more than $300 billion). These regions are leading the global race in green technologies, driven by regulatory reforms, strategic plans, and the increasing market and societal demand for clean energy.
attributes.contentD: Investing in renewable energy is not just an ecological responsibility – it is quickly becoming a financial imperative. Thanks to technological advancements and economies of scale, solar panel prices have dropped by over 30% in the last two years, while the cost of key battery materials – like lithium and cobalt – has also significantly decreased. These changes have made renewable energy more competitive than ever.
attributes.contentE: Because of this, investors worldwide – from large institutional funds to private companies and individual investors – are increasingly turning to projects in solar and wind energy, energy storage, and green hydrogen technologies.
attributes.contentG: While traditional energy investments have often been seen as more stable, private investments in renewable energy are proving their resilience, predictability, and profitability. According to data from Goldman Sachs Asset Management, returns from private infrastructure projects in renewable energy range from 8% to 13%, with steady cash flows often tied to inflation.These projects offer investors:
attributes.contentH: * Portfolio diversification, as their performance is weakly correlated with traditional market indices
attributes.contentI: * Long-term income, thanks to concessions, power purchase agreements, and guaranteed tariffs
attributes.contentJ: * Social impact, as they support sustainable development goals, reduce emissions, and create green jobs
attributes.contentK: Electric Vehicles: A Key Component of the Energy Transition
attributes.contentL: One of the key drivers of this transition is electric vehicles (EVs), which are becoming increasingly popular among consumers and manufacturers alike. The number of electric vehicles worldwide is expected to rise in the coming years, placing significant pressure on charging infrastructure.
attributes.contentN: To support this growth, it is essential to develop alternative energy sources for charging, which would reduce dependence on fossil fuels and enable more sustainable transport. Since electric vehicles do not emit CO₂ while driving, it is crucial that the energy used to charge them also comes from clean, renewable sources. Otherwise, the overall ecological benefits of switching to electric vehicles could be diminished. Therefore, it is critical for governments, companies, and investors to focus on expanding networks of charging stations powered by solar energy, wind, or other forms of green energy.
attributes.contentP: Governments around the world have recognized the importance of accelerating the energy transition. In the United States, the Inflation Reduction Act has provided over $370 billion in support for clean energy projects. In the European Union, the Green Deal ensures a regulatory framework and investment funds for the development of green infrastructure, energy efficiency, and industrial decarbonization. Thanks to these frameworks, the private sector has clear guidelines and specific incentives to invest – further reducing risk and speeding up project implementation.
attributes.contentS: In addition to the economic benefits, investing in renewable energy is also a moral obligation to future generations. Climate change, air pollution, and unstable weather patterns require urgent action. Every kilowatt-hour of energy produced from solar, wind, or water means fewer CO₂ emissions, less reliance on fossil fuel imports, and a cleaner environment for all.
attributes.contentT: Investing in renewable energy not only helps mitigate climate change but also builds a more resilient society that is less vulnerable to price shocks and geopolitical crises. Renewable energy sources are no longer a niche – they are the main direction of global energy development. Their economic sustainability, government support, and increasing demand make them an ideal choice for investors looking for security, stability, and long-term growth.More about this toppic read here: https://www.iea.org/topics/investment
